titleStmt.title: Prevalence of Scedosporium species and Lomentospora prolificans in patients with cystic fibrosis in a multicenter trial by use of a selective medium

affiliation.orgName: Klinik für Pädiatrie m.S. Pneumologie u. Immunologie
Institut für Medizinische Mikrobiologie und Hygiene
Institut für Med. Mikrobiologie und Hygiene

analytic.title: Prevalence of Scedosporium species and Lomentospora prolificans in patients with cystic fibrosis in a multicenter trial by use of a selective medium

biblStruct.note: Received 10 October 2014; revised 18 December 2014; accepted 21 December 2014

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Objective: Detection of hyphomycetes of the Scedosporium apiospermum complex and Lomentospora prolificans (Sac-Lp) is not yet standardized.
Prevalence rates in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) and the resistance pattern of these pathogens in Germany are unknown.
Methods: In a one-year prospective study 11 laboratories used a selective medium for isolation of Sac-Lp, examining N 11,600 respiratory samples from 2346 patients with CF.
Isolates were identified by molecular methods and tested for susceptibility to antifungal drugs.
Results: The prevalence of Sac-Lp in patients with CF in Germany varied from 0.0 to 10.5% (mean: 3.1%) among the clinical centres.
The benefit of the selective medium SceSel + compared to standard media for fungi was documented for N 5000 samples.
High antifungal resistance was detected in the S. apiospermum complex, and the multiresistance of L. prolificans was confirmed.
Conclusion: Microbiology laboratories should be aware of these resistant species in patients with CF and consider using a selective medium.
In up to 50% of patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) the respiratory tract is colonized by moulds of the genus Aspergillus [1].
The prevalence of non-Aspergillus spp.
moulds may be underestimated due to overgrowth of bacteria or some fast growing Aspergillus species, e.g., Aspergillus fumigatus, on routine media [1,2].

Fungi of the Scedosporium apiospermum complex and Scedosporium prolificans, recently renamed as Lomentospora prolificans [3] (Sac-Lp), are the second most frequent colonizing, allergenic or invasive fungal pathogens in patients with CF [4][5][6].

In addition, these clinically important moulds are responsible for numerous opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients or healthy individuals after near-drowning accidents or injuries [1,[7][8][9].
In a previous study on Scedosporium in patients with CF it was shown that nearly all patients were colonized by an individual strain [10].
The detection rate of hyphomycetes of Sac-Lp depends on careful cultural and molecular diagnostic procedures and is not yet standardized [11,12].
Prevalence rates from patients with CF are only reported for single centres in Europe and Australia, ranging from 3.4% to 17.4% [2,[13][14][15].
Infections by these species can be dramatic due to a high resistance to antifungal agents [16].

Previous studies in small cohorts demonstrated, that the use of a semi-selective medium such as YPDA supplemented with cycloheximide [2] or the more recently described SceSel + culture medium [12,14,17] is important for a cultural detection of Sac-Lp.
The aim of this study was to obtain representative data on the prevalence of hyphomycetes belonging to Sac-Lp in patients with CF in Germany.

For this, in a prospective multicentre study 11 geographically distributed CF centres of the network "Scedosporium in patients with CF" examined respiratory samples including SceSel + agar for their isolation [17].

All associated microbiological laboratories in this study included SceSel + agar [17] as a semi-selective medium to detect fungi of the Sac-Lp in respiratory samples of patients with CF during a one-year period from January 1st until December 31st, 2011.
Among other components this agar contains benomyl to prevent the growth of Aspergillus spp.
SceSel + agar was produced in quarterly batches and used after passing quality control.

After pre-treatment with a mucolyticum the clinical samples of patients with CF were, in addition to commonly used media for fungi, plated on this SceSel + agar and incubated for 10 days at 36 ± 1 °C.

The isolates were microscopically pre-identified on the genus level and sent to the reference laboratory for scedosporiosis at the Robert Koch Institute (RKI), Berlin, Germany, for final identification using molecular methods (ITS sequencing or species-specific hybridization on an LCD microarray [18].

Antifungal susceptibility testing was performed according to the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CSLI) M38-A2 guidelines, modified by reading at that time when the growth control was positive (most often after 48 h of incubation).
More than 11,600 respiratory samples from 2346 patients with CF in Germany were included in this study.
In total, 161 isolates of the S. apiospermum complex and/or L. prolificans from 73 patients were recovered.
These patients had an age range of between 6 and 51 years (mean 22 years).
No significant gender-related differences in age, calculated by Student's t-test (t value = 0.817), could be detected (see Table 1).
The prevalence differed from 0.0% to 10.5% within the 11 CF centres.
The overall prevalence of Sac-Lp in patients with CF was 3.1%.

The most frequently detected species were S. apiospermum (49%) and Scedosporium boydii (29%), while significantly less L. prolificans (12%), Scedosporium aurantiacum (5%) and Scedosporium minutispora (5%) were cultured.
In the case of six patients with CF (8%) two different species of Sac-Lp could be isolated.
In centre A (Hannover) the benefit of SceSel + agar was analysed in detail (Table 2): In 5472 samples (from 642 patients) 39 isolates of Sac-Lp from 19 patients were cultured.
On SceSel + agar 95% of all isolates (37/39) could be cultured directly from clinical samples.
All isolates were able to grow on SceSel + agar.

Due to the simultaneous presence of some Aspergillus species in clinical samples, tedious and time-consuming isolation procedures were necessary in 26 out of 39 specimens (67%) using only other media, e.g., yeast extract agar.

18/39 isolates (46%) have been (simultaneously) recovered on non-selective media, like chocolate agar and yeast extract agar within 10 days of incubation at 36 °C, whereas 13 isolates could be isolated only by applying the SceSel + agar.
The resistance pattern of clinical isolates is shown in Table 3 and Fig. 1.
Apart from the multiresistance in the case of L. prolificans, voriconazole showed a prominent in vitro activity to the species tested.
The lowest voriconazole minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) values were revealed in the case of S. minutispora and S. aurantiacum.
As expected, resistance to amphotericin B was confirmed in 96% (109/113) of the tested isolates.
In patients with CF persistent colonization and infection with Scedosporium species are still an underestimated issue.
Our data confirm the high rate of false negative results when not using a selective medium, especially when patients are co-colonized by some Aspergillus species [1,11].
Due to this, 54% of the Sac-Lp isolates would have been missed, as documented in one centre.
The missing growth of two Scedosporium isolates from clinical samples on SceSel + agar may be explained by sample partitioning and low fungal load of the specimen.

Using the opportunity of the standardized usage of SceSel + agar for examination of respiratory samples of patients with CF in the present study, about 28% of all estimated patients with CF in Germany were analysed for cultural detection of Scedosporium within a period of one year [19].
However, the prevalence of Sac-Lp in this study cohort in Germany was similar or lower (3.1%)
than the previously described 3.4% to 17.4% [2,[13][14][15].

Although SceSel + agar is not a standard medium in CF diagnostic procedure, we strongly advocate the usage of a selective medium to reliably detect fungi of the S. apiospermum complex and L. prolificans in respiratory samples of patients with CF.
It remains unclear whether the higher prevalence in several other smaller studies is related to a local higher environmental burden, geographical differences or therapeutic regimens.
Also in the presented study the prevalence of these fungi varied in patients from different centres.
This may be impacted by human activities, especially in industrial areas, compared to a lower detection in natural areas [20].
It could be speculated that patients living in a more rural area in Germany may be less frequently exposed to Sac-Lp compared to patients from urban regions.

The prevalence of these moulds in patients from different centres may be influenced by multiple factors, e.g., patient's environment and outdoor activities, their treatment or medical care in a centre quite far from their homes.

The major species detected in this study was S. apiospermum, followed by S. boydii whereas a higher prevalence of S. boydii compared to S. apiospermum is reported from France [21]; in a further study S. apiospermum was found only [13].

Since there are no reliable data on the environmental distribution of Sac-Lp in these two countries and the method of identification varies, a discussion of the prevalence of distinct species within Sac-Lp in patients with CF is highly speculative.
The reported number of S. apiospermum cases in one study is questionable since the isolates were identified by macro-and micromorphology only [13].
A comparison of data is only possible if identification of isolates is based on molecular methods and the current taxonomy.
The ITS region of rDNA proved to be species specific enough to separate the single species within the S. apiospermum complex and to identify L. prolificans.
For further epidemiological studies characterization of isolates, e.g., by MLST, is mandatory [10].
The MICs of the antifungals against the species varied considerably, stressing the need of antifungal testing and careful decision on effective antifungal drugs.
Voriconazole proved to be the most effective drug in vitro, despite a high resistance in the case of L. prolificans (see Fig. 1).

While a previous study revealed S. aurantiacum as the less susceptible species within the S. apiospermum complex [22], in the present study S. aurantiacum proved to be susceptible to voriconazole, which is in line with recently published data [16].
Overall, there is no essential difference in the resistance patterns of isolates in our study from Germany compared to the comprehensive study by Lackner et al.
To clarify whether the contradictory results are due to a geographical difference or to patient-related data, a greater number of isolates have to be tested.
To our knowledge, this is the largest prospective study to date analysing the prevalence of Sac-Lp under routine laboratory diagnostic settings.
No data on a possible antimycotic pretreatment could be documented within this study.
The clinical relevance for the individual patients harbouring Scedosporium species or L. prolificans is currently being analysed in a follow-up project.
Every microbiological laboratory should be aware of these fungi, therefore the routine addition of a selective medium for Scedosporium is highly recommended.

Scedosporium-Besiedlungen des Respirationstraktes bei Mukoviszidose-Patienten" FKZ 1369-419-424.
The authors wish to thank Ursula Erikli for copyediting.

MICs (μg/ml) of antifungals against isolates of the S. apiospermum complex and L. prolificans in patients with CF.
MIC = minimum inhibitory concentration; MEC = minimal effective concentration; AMB = amphotericin B; CAS = caspofungin; ICZ = itraconazole; PCZ = posaconazole; VCZ = voriconazole.
Number of patients with cystic fibrosis, analysed samples, S. apiospermum complex and L. prolificans-positive patients and gender and age distribution for each participating centre.
Detection of Scedosporium species and L. prolificans in the centre Hannover.
(39 isolates in 5472 samples from 642 patients).
